column4: hi all, firstly sorry for the stupid question, but does anyone know if I *need* to install an X server on a machine that's only going to be used via Xming logon?
Bloodhunter: can I recommend a more appropriate channel?  try /join nvidia
/join nvidia without the quotes
is that Ubuntu-specific ?
just an idea
well, IIRC Ubuntu has some builtin logic to help you do this, so why not Google for it ?
it's at least 3 times easier than using nvidia's guidelines...
you have to do at least 3 distinct things to get the vanilla nvidia binary to work, and Ubuntu pretty much does them for you
I've installed Nvidia drivers before - the best place I found was form the Ubuntu getting started guide, but that's just my experience
indeed, but it differs enough from the official nvidia way that newcomers probably don't want to be confused by it
what was it ? :)
I have Ubuntu server set up running SSH and SAMBA as a fileserver - do I need to install an X server on the machine in order to run graphical programs remotely (via Xming)
I asked this over in xorg, but none of them knew exactly

ah I see it - well, you *need* the libraries so that X clients can connect to your remote X server, and AFAIK they're only fully installed when you do the full Xorg installation.. you should just go with xorg and tell it not to start up a local X server automatically
cheers, I'll try and figure out how to do that
it is mnore relevant to tell your display manager (xdm, gdm, kdm) to do the right things, like A. not start the local X server, and B. open up XDMCP to network requests
have you had any experience with Xming?
so, gdm config, not so much Xorg config
I tried it a while back, and if you just set an Ubuntu desktop to allow remote X, it works pretty much out of the box... haven't had that much luck with a remote server though
I'm pretty much a newcomer, so to be clear I need to    1) install x- server?    2) somehow edit the startup scripts(? ) to prevent it starting into gdm
halfway there.. you do need to install X, yes - it's called xorg-server or something, but you do want to start a display manager - it just should not start  the X server.
ok
connecting to a remote X machine is done with the XDMCP protocol, which is part of the display manager - gdm in Ubuntu's default case
in which case does it matter which I choose?
(it'll probably be gdm)
a little more technical: it is actually gdm that tells the X system to use the local X server as the users' display - but it could as well be a remote display
I'll tell you the whole story, just for clarity.  I'm thinking of setting up a fileserver and at the moment I've installed Ubuntu server 6.06 on VMware and had a play
I'm running 606LTS as a file/web/mail/whatever server here, it's a beaut
what I want ideally is a minimalist install on hardware but that I can log into using Xming
that =kinda contradicts itself.. you won't have a minimalist install when X is possible
it was easy enough to set up so I'm happy with it so far on VMware - will be moving to hardware in a week or so
do you know what hardware ?
well temporarily a PIII 450, 1G RAM 40G HDD
1GB of ram is in-sa-neey :)
mine has 256, and it uses about 160 of that with samba, Postfix, apache, mysql, named, mailscanner etc. running
well I don't know what to do relaly my *main* PC (Windows box) has an AMD x2 3800 3G RAM 400G HDDs so I was going to doneate some RAM from that
not possible, believe me
I might not donate any RAM at all as I have 128 + 256 sticks on the PIII mobo
a P3 uses single rate SDRAM, at 133MHz max., while an AMD 64 uses DDR SDRAM at 266MHz minimum - they're not ecxactly compatible
to be honest I've not looked at the RAM to see if they are compatible so probably
oops
384 is  more than enough for the foreseeable future
good good
things you *do* want in a server are: 1. ECC memory, if you can get it, and 2. redundant storage.
1. is a nice option to have, but 2. is non-negotiable - use a mirrored system disk at least

the thing is I was thinking of long-term - I kind of want a system with RAID (when I feel brave enough) and I was wondering if it's possible to have it spin down the HDDs so they don't get too much wear and then use a large RAM buffer and only spin up the HDDS when needed
RAID requires no courage - only money :) if you use Linux softraid it works fast, simple, and very very dependably
for a server, spinning down the HDs is not an option.
yeah I've heard it's faster than hardware RAID in most cases
RAID 5 would be ideal
well, it's obviously not, if you use decent hardware.. but it is a lot less expensive, and it can combine drives from any type of interface

the last one is really the most important - if you get, say, 4 drives on a 4-drive RAID card, then that's it - you cannot expand beyond it, and if you decide to put in another 4x card then you'd get 2 arrays at best - with softraid you just set up all 8 drives to give you RAID 10 or 5 or 50 or whatever
whether RAID5 is ideal really depends on what you're going to use it for
in terms of pure storage, yes - it is

well I like RAID 5 as a balance between fault tolerance and speed, however thinking about it striping (RAID 1?) might be better as it'll be accedd over a wireless network therefore wont need the speed
accessed*
I've read a bit about RAID and it seems simple enough to set up in Linux
basically I want a VERY reliable box that I can sit in a cupboard and not worry too much about, but I'd like to be able to compile stuff with it every now and again
yes, md raid is very easy to set up - you can even let Ubuntu server do it for you while installing
Hawkev: how cheap is cheap though?  I think software RAID is probably right for me
that's what I did - mine is running off 2x 36GB ultra160 on an adaptec card
you see that's not really cheap compared to what I'm looking at shelling out for the rest of the HW
if the choice is between Linux md RAID and a fakeraid card, forget the card - it's useless
a *real* RAID controller will start at around $300, for 4 SATA channels
exactly!
but that will also give you on-board cache RAM and battery backup - which is a little more than you need for  a home setup
I can get an SATA mobo for 30 (~$45) and software RAID a lot easier!
I thought you already had the board ? you mentioned a P3 450 somewhere back
RAID = redundant array of inexpensive disks - it's a way to either make your storage FASTER, MORE RELIABLE or both

login*

and is normally only prodded via SSH or similar for maintenance
